Male Pt presents with mother for Initial Orthodontic Consultation Note: * On time: on time Covering Faculty: [DOCTOR] Chief Concern: " "I want to straighten my lower teeth" " RMHx: No contraindications to today's consultation. Significant Findings: Pt is slightly Cl III molar but facial profile is convex and did not change shoe sizes in the past year RDHx: Pt had cleaning in November, no restorative work pending EOE: WNL IOE: Moderate lower crowding bilateral Cl III molars R Molar Classification: 3 L Molar Classification: 3 TMJ: ( No ) Crepitus, ( No ) , Yes Clicking of TMJ, Pain on Palpation, ( No ) Hx of Trauma Recommendations: Yes Records to be taken, CBCT ( Full + Report ) , IO and EO photographs, Scan/Models of Maxillary and Mandibular Arches. * NV: Consultation of Tx Options, Begin Tx upon approval

FAC: PK All primary teeth have exfoliated. However, pt. was playing goal keeper and while diving for a save, chipped his UR1 and presents with a crown/root fracture. Noticeable plaque build up on the UR1-4. Pt. is very sensitive and turned head away abruptly while using scaler to scrape away plaque. Recommended that the pt. schedule an appt. with the pediatric dept. to have to tooth looked at ASAP. Father wanted to konw if we could simply extract the tooth. Discussed with father that tooth could potentially be saved and that a PA radiograph should be taken first. NV: INRECS and start ortho tx once UR1 is restored

Clinic:
OR .XRayTech
Male Pt presents with mother for Initial Orthodontic Consultation Note: In 7th grade. Favorite class is math. Prefers to be called On time: 5 minutes late Covering Faculty: [DOCTOR] Chief Concern: " "I want to fix my smile." " RMHx: No contraindications to today's consultation. Significant Findings: UR1 fractured crown secondary to trauma from playing soccer. Tooth is apically and facially displaced. Not enough room in the arch for UR1. UR1 recently had RCT and will need a restoration to restore proper size and shape. Full cusp class II bilaterally Deep bite RDHx: Sees dentist at UOP. Recently had RCT on UR1. Mesiodens can be seen radiographically between U1s. EOE: Convex profile, retrognathic mandible. No asymmetry Competent lips IOE: Crown fracture UR1. UR1 is positioned facially and apically. Maxillay crowding. Clinic:
Reviewed treatment options with patient including non-extraction and extraction plans. Recommended fixed appliances rather than Invisalign due to need for significant root movement of lower posterior teeth. Explained to patient that non-extraction plan may add approx 6 mo to treatment time due to need to distalize molars with TADs and also would require occlusal coverage of lower 7's to prevent supraeruption. Discussed extraction plan including extraction of L4's or L5's. Explained to pt that extraction of L4's may be more ideal than L5's due to perio defect on L4's. However, would like pt to check with a dentist regarding vitality of L5's before extraction decision is made. Finishing with Invisalign may be possible. NV: Bonding 5/12, do not engage wire on lower until extractions are done. Check with patient regarding vitality test on L5's

Clinic:
Pt presents with father with no CC, referred from UOP Pedo clinic. Pt has class I molars (slight class III on left) with class I canines. Severe crowding in upper arch (U-shaped maxilla) and moderate crowding in lower arch. UR5/6 are in posterior crossbite. U2s are in anterior crossbite with L2s and UR1 in crossbite with LR1. Midlines are on, lower arttached gingiva appears adequate. Prominent marginal ridges on upper incisors. OB is 0-3mm, OJ is 0.5 mm. No TMJ CC. Jaw deviates slightly to right upon opening and returns to midline upon closure. Recommended treatment is to extract 4 bicuspids to resolve upper and lower crowding to prevent profile change.

Clinic:
Appliance Adjustment Today the patient came in with her [GUARDIAN]. The patient reported that she woke up today and the left side of the Herbst appliance was loose. The screw came out and the left bar was detached. She brought in the screw and I tested to see if there was internal stripping or a defect with the screw. No problem was detected so I put the bar back into the screw and screwed it into place. I used the appropriate L shaped wrench to tighten the screw and i checked the right side tightness which was fine. I reminded the patient to resist the urge to play with the appliance and to let us know if any problems arise during the holiday season. NV: [DOCTOR] for check up

OCS activated between UL1&UL2, and CCS placed between UL2&UL3. 3. PC UL1 to UR7 to close residual spaces on UR and shift midline to R [GUARDIAN] came in today. [GUARDIAN] insisted that the patient looks worse than when he started and had multiple questions/complaints. His main questions were, "Why are there still spaces on the top?" and "Why are you taking even more teeth out (aka wisdom teeth)?" [GUARDIAN] was overall rude and disrespectful. While showing the patient's initial and progress photos, I explained the following: 1. The upper 4's were extracted as pt initially had a large overjet (I said "overbite" for patient's better understanding). After extracting the 4's, most of the extraction spaces were used to retract the upper front teeth back to reduce the overjet. 2. The reason spaces are present around the upper 2's is because we had planned for peg lateral buildups. This was a part of the initial treatment plan, to which [GUARDIAN] and patient both agreed to according to the previous orthodontic residents' notes. Final restorations need to be done at the dentist once braces are debonded. 3. The lower 8's are mesially angulated and are against the distal of the lower 7's. There is an operculum covering the lower 7's and the 8's will not erupt naturally due to the angulation. This impaction may cause the patient pain and discomfort in the long run. While it is up to the patient and the guardian to remove the 8's, this is a recommendation for the patient's oral health rather than for orthodontics. On explaining #2, it was obvious that [GUARDIAN] was unahppy that he had to visit another dentist and pay for permanent restorations (crowns/veneers). Upon explaining #3, [GUARDIAN] accused "And who's fault is that? Because you guys took teeth out and the teeth are now tipping." I explained that this not true as no teeth were extracted on the lower, and that mesiallywisdom teeth are very common. [GUARDIAN] also said that the extractions were done without his approval and since the patient is a minor and the [GUARDIAN] only speaks Spanish, "they don't know." He also complained that he was not allowed to enter the operatory during the extraction at the OS clinic, and said that this is unacceptable as the patient is still a minor. At the end of the conversation, I asked [GUARDIAN] what he would like us to do to make the patient look better, as he kept insisting that the patient looks worse with "spaces everywhere" and that we "did not do things right." He pointed out the shifted midline, for which I explained that the midline shift will be corrected once we finish treatment. [GUARDIAN] said "Well then do what you need to do, if he looks good at the end I'll be happy. But if he doesn't look good, you know what's going to happen." After this conversation, [GUARDIAN] stayed in the operatory while I proceeded with today's appointment. NV: UL2 buildup if sufficient space has been achieved
